Posts.Content: May 28, 2008 09:43AM Tina337 wrote: Sheila, thanks for bumping this thread. Everyone seemed to have disappeared. . . Yes, it is a major thrill to put tops on over my head. It's those little things that bring joy! As you say, each type of surgery has different requirements as far as type of bra/no bra to wear. As one who has expanders, I've discovered the body shaping tops without a shelf, which are supportive like a sports bra, but thinner and minus the bulky seams. I prefer the tank style for certain dresses and shirts. However, I don't know what these (almost girdle-like) garments are supposed to fit like, but I am usually a size 4, and I am wearing a size large tank and it still has lots of support (and this was with no fill at all). I can't imagine who's wearing the smaller sizes (or even why), unless it's to create a smooth silhouette under a slinky dress. Finally found a front zip bra that I like that's comfy, too, but that took a special trip to a mastectomy shop. It's a whole wardrobe adjustment period, esp. with the recent change from fairly cool to warm weather, but I don't want to go crazy and spend money on stuff that I won't be able to wear later. It's a tough stage, but being able to put things over-the-head increases choices big time. I've made the rounds at Target and K-Mart for a few pieces of cheaper short-term clothes, and Kohl's and Boscov's for undergarments. I started physical therapy last week, went twice. She said I was doing very well, so I'm off the paranoia wagon about being way behind range-of-motion-wise. I've been trying to walk a few times a week, and find this goes a long way for lifting my spirits. The rainy weather had put a slight damper on things for a few days, but now it's just beautiful outside. I've been hanging out over on the Breast Reconstruction thread since I've started my fills. Yesterday was my second one, and, same as the first, left me feeling quite uncomfortable. Less pain than the first time, but I prepared a little better -- hot shower, valium, and pain pill at the ready for the car ride if I sensed a start in pain. I did start to feel it, so I popped the pain med and was able to stay ahead of the pain curve. Today I feel slightly swollen, and I have a PT appt., so we'll see how that goes. I think we'll have to go easy this session. Sheila, it really is hard to not do things we're not allowed to do. Every once in a while I find myself picking up something a little heavy, and think, oh carp!, put that thing down. I hope your PS gives you good news about your flap and that it is healing nicely. Your path is so much tougher than mine, girl, and I have such admiration and respect for your determination. I feel like such a weenie complaining about my much smaller issues. Hugs, Tina

Posts.Content: Apr 11, 2008 05:40PM - edited Apr 11, 2008 05:41PM by Tina337 Hi, April gals. I just returned home today after bilateral mastectomy/expander surgery on Wed. I'm having some pain but trying to pop those pain killers on schedule to keep things under control. Also have a rash that could have been caused by a few things and taking benedryl to calm that. Results: no lymph involvement, so only sentinel node was removed. However, the big news is that I made the absolutely right decision when I went for the bilateral mast even though DCIS had only been found in right breast. Because of the other 5 biopsies (in both breasts), I was concerned that something had gone undetected. My surgeon got the pathology report back last night and stopped by to see me. Besides the diagnosed DCIS in the right breast, there were two additional areas in the R breast (another DCIS and a microinvasion). Two areas of DCIS were found in the left breast as well. Boy, do I feel like I just flew under the radar. My surgeon told me that he'll have me see the oncologist, but he's fairly sure that there will be no additional treatment. Wow, wow, I am so glad I went with my gut instinct about this, even though three surgeons had said a lumpectomy/radiation/tamox would be as effective as a mast. I'm also grateful to my primary physician who urged me to have the bilateral mast. I guess because she wan't the surgeon, she didn't feel she had to be so tight-lipped about my decision. In response to aurabelle and 1965Sally's post above: "I am getting more and more depressed as I wait for mine on April 30th. I had thought I would be eager to get it over with - that's what I was feeling before it got scheduled. Now I think I'm starting to grieve and worry." I know exactly how you feel. When you're in the phase of gathering info, there's an ability to focus a little more abstractly about your condition. Once all the facts are in, decision is made (if choice is possible), and surgery scheduled, it becomes a reality. My doctor gave me a prescription for xanax and urged me to use it in the days leading up to the surgery. I used it daily and when I wasn't tearful, I tried to think positively. You will make it, both of you!!

Posts.Content: May 29, 2008 02:53AM Tina337 wrote: Sheila, have you visited a mastectomy store? I have one camisole which has pockets for pads which were included with the camisole. They have more structure to hold the pad than the shelf style camis. The brand I bought was Amoena, but there are a couple other brands out there. You could wear the one side with the pad and go without on your braless side. I go without the pads and wear the cami to sleep in or when I'm feeling ultra sensitive and don't want too much pressure. My insurance covered this purchase and the store took care of the paperwork. I would definitely ask the PS about a script for PT. One thing I did at home after I got my script but before I could get on the PT schedule was to put on some music in my living room and dance by myself. Didn't do anything super fast or any jerky movements, but something with a medium beat that made me want to move. I found that I could move my arms in a variety of motions/angles and let my body be my guide. I didn't force anything, just enjoyed the flow/movement that let me stretch slightly. It's also a great substitute for walking on rainy days. I think the key is to go easy and don't do anything that hurts, but I certainly feel a positive light stretch. It never makes me sore afterward, and I think it makes my back feel better as well. I still do it just because I like it. Gotta admit PT pushes me more than I was doing on my own, but it's good because you know you're doing things in the right position, how far to stretch, etc. The second time I went the therapist actually stretched me out as I was lying on a table. I could really feel how tight I am in certain places, esp. in the arm pits. There was some discomfort, but nothing intolerable, and she always made sure she wasn't pushing too much. I think the bottom line is that there is going to be some discomfort in order to get back to your starting point. Not pain, but a little effort over time. The therapist has slowly increased the number of exercises I do there and I am supposed to do them on off days at home as well. I went through PT a while back when I broke my foot, so I know that you have to force yourself to do the exercises if you want the full range of motion back. (The way they tortured me back then doesn't even compare to what I'm doing now, but that was a whole different kind of injury.) Talk about putting stuff over your head -- it's a lot easier to get it over than to get it off. A few weeks ago I had to ask some poor clerk at the Target fitting room to come into my room and help me get a shirt off. It was rather embarrassing, because I had taken off my cami and was totally exposed. She was quite nice and kind about the whole thing though. Taught me a lesson though about not forcing things. I still can't put tight fitting tops/dresses off and on over my head, but I'm almost there. Sheila's method for putting the opening over head first and then one arm at a time works for the bilateral as well, but agree the top has to be looser at first. Kathy, I had no saline placed in my expanders at the time of surgery. My PS said since I am slender, he wants to go slow. First fill was at 4 weeks post surgery and was 60ccs, which is what each fill will be. I go 2-3 weeks between fills and after my final fill will "rest" for 4 weeks before exchange surgery. Just got all this info yesterday so I could plan my summer. I have 2 or 3 more fills. Looks like exchange surgery will be Sept. I sure hope you get those final drains removed next week! My goodness, it is the one thing that makes you feel human again!

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2011 05:03AM Tina337 wrote: MMM - I have truncal LE, and earlier this year I had surgery to undo my implant reconstruction. I was concerned it would exacerbate it. I went for MLD with my LE therapist about three times in the two months prior to my surgery. I also became very diligent with doing self MLD and drinking lots of water, and all the positive things that keep my LE stable. For me, low salt in my diet and limited alcohol help keep my LE in check. I also planned to have MLD for a few weeks post surgery to help promote lymphatic flow while things were healing. I did have to wear compression more often for a while.  Because my truncal LE somewhat effects my non-node side, I wanted a neck IV and BP taken in my calf during surgery. I happened to read here about Dr. Marga Massey, a PS who does flap and tissue transfer reconstruction surgeries. She also has trained in LE care and has her LANA certification. She does MLD on her patients prior to surgery and she then wraps their at risk arms to help limit fluid traveling to the arms during surgery. She seemed to be the perfect fit for me as far as LE care even though I was deconstructing and not having any further reconstruction surgery. So, I travelled to Charleston, SC and had my surgery done by her. I do believe my proactive care at home prior to surgery, Dr. Massey's pre-operative care, and the care I received at the hospital immediately after surgery (MLD that night in my hospital room), the MLD I received daily for two weeks following surgery, and then twice a week for a few more weeks all helped minimize the impact of surgery on my truncal LE. I also was diligent with self care in the few weeks after surgery, keeping well hydrated, and all the positives I mentioned doing prior to surgery. I was on an antibiotic for two weeks post surgery. I would suggest taking proactive care prior to and after surgery with MLD and good self care would be of primary importance. Best to make sure ahead of time the surgeon and hospital are aware of your LE and that no IV or BP would be used on that side. I like to think since they are going in for node work on that side that this would be obvious, but I would make sure to discuss and have on record. I'd also mention to staff the day of surgery.

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2008 07:44PM Tina337 wrote: Kathy, I can't speak to your diagnosis and the urgency of its treatment, but I have to agree with how important it is to feel confident and comfortable with your PS. Any and all questions should be welcomed and answered honestly and patiently. My diagnostic process lasted from mid-November through late January 2008. I had DCIS diagnosed immediately in one area, and then had five more biopsies that were spread out until the very end. I was feeling so-so about my breast surgeon, but stuck things out. I always felt like I had to bang on the table to get her attention, get a follow-up appt. in a reasonable time, get her staff to return my calls, etc. When I met with her, I felt like I had her attention, but I just always had this nagging thought about her. Her office was chaotic, so I wondered if she'd be fully attentive during my surgery. It was just my gut instinct. I also didn't care for my primary physician, and at that point I decided to bail out on her, too. So, I found a new primary physician and got a referral for a new surgeon. I took two steps back when I could have been having my surgery within a very short time, but ultimately, I'm so glad I switched. My new breast surgeon is terrific and he hooked me up with a different plastic surgeon, oncologist, radiation oncologist, and I was able to ask all kinds of questions and make an informed decision about the type of surgery and treatment that was best for me. I felt like a weight had been lifted off my shoulders and I knew I was going to be in good hands. After being held at bay by my first surgeon for months, my current breast surgeon's office was able to book an operating room for him and my PS to do my bilat mast and expanders within a week and a half's time. Good docs care for their patients and can make things happen for them in the time it needs to. Having come through surgery, I still feel so pleased with my choices. Both doctors were attentive to me while I was in the hospital post surgery and have been available via phone since I've been home. I know I will be comfortable meeting with them for upcoming follow-up appts. over the next months. I hope you are able to take the time to meet with one or two plastic surgeons. A consultation shouldn't take more than a 1/2 hour. Your breast surgeon and you and your husband can explain your concern about how soon your surgery can be arranged. I hope you are able to work things out. You deserve to have the best care possible and a plastic surgeon that wants to make you happy with your new body. Tina

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2008 08:47PM Tina337 wrote: I totally can relate to your anxiety and fear of the testing and surgery procedures. It was very hard for me. Some people struggle more with anxiety than others, but I want you to know you can get through this process. I had six biopsies, two were stereotactic (using digital mammo), two were via ultrasound, and two were via MRI (which is similar to stereotactic, except that it's "live" vs. a single snapshot, i.e., you are held in the clamped position for the whole time). I also had to have dye injections in preparation for my bilateral mastectomy, the usual IVs, etc. I am petrified of needles, and I don't consider myself a brave person in general. What I did during these procedures and and the moments leading up to surgery was to practice mindful meditation, choosing something to focus on, most often my breathing. If I kept my eyes open, I would find a neutral point in the room on which to focus while the procedure was occurring. I was able to maintain a single position without moving during regular MRIs, which required about 1/2 hr. of laying completely still, and then during the biopsies via MRI which lasted a bit longer. I suggest you first practice focusing on your breathing during a non-stressful time so that you can become familiar with the concept. I used a couple of books by Jon Kabat-Zinn to learn the practice of mindful meditation, and they helped me throughout my several month diagnostic process, and now it is useful in my healing and expansion process. It is also very helpful in dealing with pain. I did take ativan to calm myself down before each procedure, but the focused breathing is what got me through every process. I asked questions ahead of time to know what to expect, and then told them how I would be working to manage my fear and anxiety during the process. I told them unless anything was wrong, I'd only be answering with simple verbal responses or hand movements. Please don't let your fear prevent you from getting the best possible treatment. We all are scared during this time, but have to find that inner strength to get through. You will find this strength, and we will all be here to support you. Hugs, Tina

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 12:51AM - edited Feb 26, 2012 04:48PM by Tina337 Papyrus, since I've had the experience of both implant reconstruction and then removing implants and deconstructing due to complications, I certainly understand your concern. Only in undoing my reconstruction did I realize how much this "simple" surgery had altered my body. I don't blame you for being conflicted, as the lat flap recon is even more involved. Are you athletic and very active in certain sports? I would ask the women here whether or how much implant recon and lat flap recon have limited their abilities. What I can say about my own experience with implant recon, is I wish I had never done it. It caused me a lot of pain, and now that I am flat, I feel so much better. I go without prosthetics and I feel good about my self image. In fact, I think I look better flat than I did with the implants. I know there are so many here on these forums who are very happy with their recons though. I am not trying to be negative or anti-implant or recon, it's just that after being on BC.org for four years, I know that implants aren't as easy as they sound. Reoperations, revisions, and fat grafting are common. I don't usually post all this info, but since you said you are worried, I thought you might appreciate. It's a lot different than hearing women two months out from exchange surgery saying how much they love their implants. If you want unbiased info, then read the FDA's info on silicone implants in the documents below. Pages 25-32 in the first document has Mentor's three-year follow up study on recon patients with silicone implants. Tables 1-6 are interesting. www.fda.gov/downloads/MedicalD...  And here is Allergan's seven-year followup on recon patients with silicone implants on pages 23-31 of their document. Tables 1-4 and Figures 1-2 are informative. http://www.fda.gov/downloads/MedicalDevices/ProductsandMedicalProcedures/ImplantsandProsthetics/BreastImplants/UCM245626.pdf

Posts.Content: May 8, 2008 11:18AM Tina337 wrote: Hi, KED Are you having a general breast MRI, or biopsy via MRI? I've had both, and while the positioning is awkward, in my opinion a general MRI could be done without Ativan or Xanax. Some general breast MRIs have you positioned with your arms at your sides, while others will have your arms raised above your head. The latter is the one I experienced. Because you are faced downward in either case, for me there wasn't any any of that claustrophobic concern. The most uncomfortable part of the experience is the "thingy", I have no idea what it's called, that rests between your breasts and left me with a bit of bruising. They will attempt to create more padding with a towel over this piece if you tell them it's bothering you. The only other unusual feeling I had during the process was when the dye was injected, which created a "cool" feeling in my arms, but it could also be that by that point my arms were just getting that uncomfortable "pins and needles" feelings when you lay in one spot too long. The IV had been put in my arm prior to laying down, so after they take several rounds of photos, they then inject the dye into the IV and then take more rounds with the dye. All in all, not that bad of an experience, and I was told each step of the process before it happened. I would say the regular MRI took about 45 min. The technicians at my center were very sensitive to privacy, had me draped with a gown and my breasts weren't exposed until I leaned downward to get into position. I know there were male staff in the center, but they were doing the computer stuff in the other room, and only women worked with me in the room. May have been a coincidence, but it was the same all three times. The noise during the procedure didn't bother me a bit, and I didn't ask for music, etc. Anyway, the two biopsies I had via MRI were more stressful and uncomfortable for me. They definitely have your arms positioned over your head for this procedure. I would recommend having a Ativan or similar relaxant for this. I don't think I was imagining this, but the procedure seemed to take longer than the regular MRI -- they had to do the dye, see if the same spots enhanced, which required the several rounds of photos, and then proceed with the biopsy. Even when taking the Ativan, I focused on my breathing, which really helped me stay calm, stay in position, and helped me feel the procedure passed more quickly. Sometimes I closed my eyes, other times I found a spot within the tube I would focus on while I was doing my breathing. Tina
Posts.Title: Breast MRI - is it "doable" w/out Ativan or the like Ked1019 Kim32

Posts.Content: Tina337 wrote: I thought this might be a helpful topic, since it hadn't occurred to me until I had to deal with it. On July 4th, I broke my foot while on vacation. I was flying home the next day, so I waited to have my foot examined and x-rayed locally. When I was on the phone with my primary's nurse to get an x-ray script faxed, she mentioned something about crutches. At that point, I realized this broken foot was going to have an impact on my well-being, and I needed to think about how it might affect my LE. When I met with the orthopedic dr., I reviewed my BC history and current condition. I told him I thought using crutches held the potential to aggravate my truncal LE since they would create pressure on a compromised lymphatic area. After discussing the break, which fortunately wasn't too bad, he fitted me with a walking boot/cast vs. a plaster cast. I had to wear it 24/7 for 4 weeks but was allowed to take off for bathing if I used a shower chair. I pressured him to let me drive when necessary - it was my right foot - which he didn't normally allow. I agreed I wouldn't divert from wearing the boot otherwise and only took the boot off once I was in the car and put it back on before I exited. I can say that except for showering and driving, I wore the boot religiously. I definitely wanted my foot to heal well and not have any lingering pain.  My other concern about having a casted foot was the lack of mobility and whether that might trigger some swelling. I used a large ball to work my abs, back and legs. I didn't stand for any exercises. I also used my bands and did my daily stretches. I really watched my diet and salt intake and drank lots of water. The boot made sleeping difficult, and I had to resort to sleep medication occasionally. The weather prior to my break had been sporadically hot and humid - unusually so for June - but I had continued to be active both inside and out without any issues. However, after the break, I did notice an increase in swelling. While we did have a major heat wave and humidity at that time, I really think my poor sleep and being sedentary was the main cause of the swelling.  Anyway, cast was removed 8am this morning. I'm feeling pretty good, just a little sore and pooped since I was on my feet and walked around until 5pm. No PT required - limited to walking on flat surfaces and bicycling for two weeks. Coincidentally, my cousin broke her foot around the same time, but it was quite serious and she was homebound for 8 wks. Besides crutches, her dr. also prescribed a knee-walker, which allowed her to cook, apply makeup, etc. while standing and gave her armpits a rest. It was a pretty nifty gadget and would be another alternative to crutches for those with LE. "Life isn't about finding yourself, life is about creating yourself." ~ George Bernard Shaw Dx 11/13/2007, DCIS, <1cm, Stage 0, Grade 1, 0/1 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2012 07:25PM Tina337 wrote: As a slight sidebar to this discussion, I just wanted to point out there are women who spend time on this forum while they are waiting to reconstruct or have had issues with reconstruction and are waiting to try again. They need support finding garments, prosthetics and have their own issues of coping with being flat. A while back I posted something and one of these gals gently reminded me of that, and she said it was sometimes hard to feel welcome here because many of us seem so anti-reconstruction. This really gave me pause and made me think about how all the forums here on BCO often overlap. Breast cancer is what brings us all together, and we all deserve support in our decisions even when they differ from others. BC diagnoses and treatments overwhelm and make it difficult to know what to choose. Some will be happy with reconstruction; some will regret it; some will be forced to undo their recon when it fails; others choose no recon and don't look back; and yet there are others who live flat by choice for many years and then decide to reconstruct. BC is a wicked ride, and as much as I rant against certain things, I always wish for my sisters to be happy with their bodies once surgeries and treatments are complete.

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2008 08:17PM Tina337 wrote: Hi, everyone. I just wanted to check back in on this conversation. I got home on Fri. from my bilateral mast/expanders surgery, and I'm feeling pretty good. I'll feel a lot more human once these drains come out, and that will hopefully be this week. I chose the bilateral mast even though there was only one confirmed area of DCIS in my right breast. I was paranoid after 6 biopsies (areas in both breasts) that something had gone undetected. With a needle biopsy, only samples of the areas were taken -- my concern was about those other cells that weren't tested but were part of what lit up on the MRI. So, I went the conservative route, even though the surgeons considered the lumpectomy to be adequate treatment, as long as I did radiation and tamox. Thurs. night my surgeon gave me the pathology results. He said I had made a wise decision. Turns out that in addition to the known area of DCIS in my right breast, there was a second area of DCIS and a small area of microinvasion. Then, to top it off, they found two areas of DCIS in my left breast as well. I am so glad I trusted my gut instinct. I did not want to be revisiting the biopsies, surgery thing again, and it appears I certainly would have. Now I have the turtle shells, and that's something that's going to take a little getting used to! I think what freaks me out the most at this point are the drains and the numbness. I've been told to expect some more swelling and bruising, but that it would then subside. I hope the numbness thing goes away at some point.

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2008 12:15PM - edited Apr 21, 2008 12:17PM by Tina337 There are conversations that address your questions about supplies. I, too, wanted to buy everything ahead of time so husband didn't have to shop once I was home. These conversations mention everything I needed and have used. As most will mention, button/zip front tops/pjs are a must. I moved everything I'd normally need in bathroom, dresser, closet, kitchen, etc. to lower height. Plastic cups and plates were helpful, too, as some of our dishes and mugs were too heavy to lift at first. Straws are good, too. This is a time to go easy and don't expect yourself to be superwoman (I'm still telling myself that!) My sister-in-law lent us their Lazy-boy chair, and it has been a lifesaver. I sleep most of the night in this for now. Also, I love the Amoena camisoles!! I went to a shop and was fitted prior to surgery and it was a positive experience. I don't know how to do a link, but the titles of the conversations are: Mastectomy..What to pack?? And what to do when return home? Shopping/packing/to-do list for surgery + recovery.... Is there a "packing list" for surgery?"

Posts.Content: Jun 20, 2012 03:18AM Tina337 wrote: MT, I do understand your mother's comment, as by the time I was diagnosed with BC at 50, I had already observed changes to my body brought on by aging. Exercise, all the right foods, etc couldn't stop it. And I mourned these "little deaths" of what it used to be like to be young, have a body that was vital in every way and looked pretty damn good in the process. After having a mastectomy, a recon gone awry (and chronic pain at the time), truncal and arm LE, I feel like I have been fast forwarded to a different decade. Undoing the recon and relief from pain gave me a few years back, but I still feel quite confused about where I am. My body looks a hell of a lot older, I can tell you that. LE is a daily reminder of the things I can no longer do, and I hate it, find it frustrating, and have had to deal with those losses. I try to approach LE as a reminder that there are many things I can do in life. I happened to like certain activities, but maybe this is a wake up to break out of doing old favorite things and try some new ones. Either that or I continue to wish for what was . . . and it's not to say I don't ever go there. Sometime it hits me like a truck out of nowhere and brings me to my knees. ALL of these changes are major life altering experiences, and no one can truly understand unless they've been there or gone through some sort of permanent body disfiguration or malfunction. It takes a while to find your way back from where you've gone. Frankly, I'm still pretty effing lost at times. But I sure am trying, and each day I'm on the lookout for friendly signposts.

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 11:46AM Tina337 wrote: Bumping my thread for Laura. We seem to be in all the same places! I'm the gal Anne is referring to that used Dr. Massey for my implant removal surgery. The ladies here are a wealth of information and so supportive and kind. I think they also moonlight as comediennes, but I digress. Their info helped me find my way in the beginning when my docs denied I had truncal LE, and they will guide you, too! I am home and feeling in a much better place emotionally. Final drain was removed Monday morning by Dr. Massey before I flew home. She came and did it while I was having my MLD session. I've also been off the pain meds, anti-nausea meds and antibiotic for several days. I feel much better without the drugs. My stomach is still flip flopping from the antibiotic - I think that's what caused it. I tried to stay on top of the probiotics on opposite times of the antibiotic so my system didn't get screwed up, but I felt very woozy for days and it really did a number on my appetite and willingness to take anything. I don't have a fever and don't think I have an infection, but I am going to monitor. I got so backed up after this surgery. I really think it's kind of related, as I'm just starting to feel regular again. Ugh, TMI. Anyway, being home and feeling better physically and minus the drain has given me some emotional strength. I feel like I'm through the darkest part, but I know I have more mourning to do. Dr. Massey talked a bit with me at our last appt, and she said this was all normal and to be expected. She said to give myself some time. It definitely took me back to the wounded period of the mastectomy and feelings of loss. I know I will get through this eventually - I do have confidence in myself and know I can process and come to terms with WHAT IS. Then I'll be pleasantly happy with any changes or improvements.  Kira, I really do think you're right about the PTSD. My diagnostic period lasted four months with six biopsies, and they were all over the place about how bad my situation was. Then I had the mastectomy and five months of expansion hell - which I think is really what did me in emotionally. The doctor's office was unsympathetic, so I felt quite isolated during that period. The prolonged pain of living with the implants over the past 2 1/2 years just added insult to injury. So, I am definitely going to be kind to myself and give my body, heart and mind time to heal. I feel so much better without the implants, and that makes me hopeful. I get a little worried about having to do a revision since I want this to be over, but I'll cross that bridge when I get to it. I'm feeling 75% better even with the post-surgery soreness, and that's a real positive! Lymphedema is still under control and wasn't affected by the flying. I wore a sleeve and glove on both arms since I have occasional truncal swelling on my non-node side and some post surgery swelling on both. Of course, I also wore my tank with inserts on both sides of my trunk below the underarm area. Thanks again for all your support and brownies!

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2010 06:25AM Tina337 wrote: Suzybelle and all my Flare Weather Friends, I, too, appreciate your honesty, Suzy. I am grateful no one on this forum has to pretend to be chipper or find a freakin' silver lining to our experience. We all know it stinks, but we're doing our best to cope and live healthy and productive lives. Every time someone goes through a flare, expresses concern about infection, or worries about something unusual, it reminds me that when I'm going through a rough time that I have a place where I can "talk" and no one will judge me for being negative or whatever. I loved "Bright-Sided" by Barbara Ehrenreich - I was grateful to find someone who expressed so many of my thoughts on the BC experience. And I remember reading the Q&A response from Rosalind Kleban that Kira posted above. That really hit home for me, too. My favorite line from her response is: "A bad attitude will cause only one thing and that is a bad day. The best reason for having a good attitude is that on that day you will enjoy yourself. But neither the good nor the bad attitude will affect the illness. It will affect the quality of the day that you are having." I just love that. While I don't want to get sucked into a routine of melancholy, sometimes circumstances are overwhelming and it's helpful to yield to the feelings of sadness, anger or pain you are experiencing that day. It isn't the end of the world. I often find that I truly feel better emotionally and physically (and more positive) once I allow myself to acknowledge and feel whatever it is I'm feeling. It sure beats faking being positive.  When I'm asked if my LE is better yet, I usually take a deep breath, and respond: "LE is just like heart disease or diabetes. It is a chronic condition that needs to be managed. I can tell you how I'm doing right now, but if you ask me another day, my symptoms could be quite different." I don't get nearly as upset as I used to when I have to explain that (again). What makes me crazy is that once my friends and family DO get it about the permanency of LE, they still don't grasp all the things I worry about - bites, cuts, sun, humidity, etc. I'm still working on that. I think people can only retain so much about other's medical conditions.  Kane, I'm right there with you, hibernating inside today with the a/c. I'm near a window, and it looks like a beautiful summer day. Used to be my favorite season, and now it's my least.  Laura! I am SO SO sorry to see you on this forum. I hope you get past the wrapping stage and into the compression garment asap. Man, you have been such a support for so many women, as well as a model of the possibilities of a successful recon with radiation. My heart goes out to you.
Posts.Title: Singing the "When is your arm going to get better?" Blues Suzybelle o2bhealthy

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 07:07AM Tina337 wrote: Oh, I forgot one of my "what if's" and it's not aimed at myself but outwardly at my original PT/LE I saw when I first noticed something felt funny in my trunk. She wasn't LANA certified, and while she acknowledged I had slight signs of LE, she never addressed with MLD. Instead, she had me doing a variety of exercises, some of which I probably shouldn't have been doing. I missed that prime window of time for taking care of early LE, and in April I had the major flare. I won't even go into the additional time I spent arguing with my BS and PS that I actually had LE and needed special treatment - NOT from my former PT. So I have this great anger toward my original PT: "How could you have done this to me!" Alternately, there's the "How could you be such an effing idiot!" and "You call yourself LE trained?" In these scenarios when I blame my original PT, the "what if" centers on "What if the PT had properly addressed my original symptoms when they were slight and barely noticeable?" Would I feel better than I do now? Whew! I can't believe I left that one out! That's directly related to the deep sadness I feel about LE being FOR LIFE. I know it doesn't help to blame another person any more than it does myself at this point, but those thoughts exist occasionally.  Suzy, I'll add another Yeehah!!! to your King Tut unwrapping tonight! Here's a little "Do as I say, not as I do" misbehaving from last night. Didn't drink as much water during the day as I usually do . . don't know why, I forgot. Anyway, I leave the house at 4:30 and I'm hit with a wall of heat. Sun blaring down on me, crap! I get in the car, turn on the air, ouch the seats are hot! I have two bottles of water with me. Thanks to Binney's comments, I've been wrapping my foot after it started to swell once my walking cast/boot came off. Sure enough, it has reduced the swelling and remaining pain significantly. I will admit I have been doing this partly in the hope that I'd be able to stand, move around or dance a little at last night's concert. Between 6:30 and 12:30 I ate dinner, had three cocktails, and danced for a good three hrs (threw caution to the wind about vinegar, spices, hydration, overheating, etc.) I had a blast! It was particularly warm at certain points, but I found where the good sources of a/c were and gravitated there as needed. Felt a little swollen in my trunk by the end of the evening, as well as my foot. Wrapped my foot but no MLD before bed. Today, truncal swelling back to norm, but foot still complaining a little. I cannot tell you how much I needed to dance like a wild woman and to just let go! By the way, I knew my top showed hints of my distorted boobies, but was the most comfy thing to wear for the occasion. I stood up straight when I walked into the venue and silently uttered MOTC's rally of Fuck Them! to anyone who might notice or care.

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2010 08:05AM - edited Nov 9, 2010 08:06AM by Tina337 Sofiajane, I am sorry you are having such pain from your reconstruction. I am glad you are asking this question though, because it is exactly what I am wondering myself. I had a bilateral mastectomy and reconstruction two years ago and have developed capsular contracture in my right implant. I also have truncal lymphedema in my right side. Both of these problems cause a lot of pain. I am learning to live with and manage the LE, but the CC has got to go.   I have been researching replacing my implants, trying to find statistics on the success of implants and for revisions for capsular contracture. Some of the info I've found makes me think I should just remove them. I am most concerned about my health, and lymphedema care is a priority. The idea of redoing the implants and having them fail and then going through surgery again might be too much for me emotionally. I have been so stuck in limbo and really need to get back to living. My goal is to have surgery in February, whatever I decide. What has me most concerned about the appearance of my chest - whether it is sunken or not - is because I haven't been able to wear a bra due to the lymphedema. The side band sits on my "hot spots" under my armpit and around back and causes the area to swell. So, I may have to go formless, and I hope it's not an ugly sight. However, the implants have always seemed too big and part of the problem with getting things to fit, so maybe I'd have better luck without them. I didn't pad during my expansion and never minded my appearance, so if I could, I would actually prefer to go formless unless an outfit/occasion made it necessary.  Susan and Mary Beth, thank you for your posts. They are both encouraging.

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2011 07:18AM Tina337 wrote: Jtsig, I am sorry you had such a bad experience. I had a similar one and have come a long way since April when I deconstructed, having my implants removed and the muscle repaired. I had a rough expansion phase but was reassured the pain would be gone once the permanent implants were in place. I was fine for three months, then I developed mild truncal lymphedema. Didn't receive good care by the first LE therapist, and within six months I had a major flare. I found a new therapist and was treated properly. At the same time, my implant started to distort and poke outward and became quite painful. My PS wasn't very helpful and minimized the issue. Eventually, after getting a second op, my original PS diagnosed capsular contracture. I didn't like the sound of any of his solutions, and by that point I had found a PT, a LE therapist, and LE physiatrist I trusted, as well as having a good friend who is a PT. My lymphedema became the overriding factor in my choice to deconstruct. I initially met with a different PS to consider replacing my implants, and I read a lot about the risks for developing CC again with replacement implants. Any surgery was a risk for exacerbating my truncal LE and causing more scar tissue, which really frightened me. I didn't think I could handle that plus another possible implant failure, which would then require another surgery. So, I opted to quit and get off the pain roller coaster in order to save my sanity. It was a tough decision, and it was definitely like revisiting the bilateral mast three years earlier. At least it brought relief, and I no longer felt imprisoned by silicone objects inside me. My chest is not a pretty sight, and one of my pectoral muscles was permanently damaged and couldn't be completely repaired. My ribs are concave from the expanders/implants, and my PS left some extra skin to minimize the impact of surgery on my LE. It is what it is, and while I had hoped for a tidier chest, I have come to terms with the new me. Because of the truncal LE, I have chosen for now to go form free and have been experimenting with new clothes. I am finally feeling good in my own skin again and confident with how I look. I am glad to be healthy and 99% pain free. Unfortunately, the LE is forever but it is much easier to cope with now. The PS who removed my implants instructed me to give myself time to mourn and get used to my chest. It sure is a tough process, but it can be done. I wish you the best, Jtsig, and hope you feel better as time passes.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2012 10:06PM Tina337 wrote: I tried NIA twice. First time was emotionally upsetting to me, as I realized how out of shape I had become from dealing with reconstruction pain. I had a little truncal swelling, but I chalked it up to lack of exercise. The second time I went in with a more positive attitude, willing to try and learn something new and do what I was able. The arm movement triggered my truncal LE and it took a few days to get it back down. I've done a lot of dancing on my own in my living room, as I have always found that enjoyable. It always includes a lot of arm movement, but I never experience swelling. I decided that the NIA for some reason just wasn't right for me. I think the reason that my home dancing works is that it lets me work naturally within my own limitations and I can set the pace, choose the music, etc. It also feels more relaxing, less stressful. Since my deconstruction and implant removal, I wonder if the NIA would still trigger my truncal LE, but I'll save that for a later day.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2012 04:06AM - edited Jan 10, 2012 08:44AM by Tina337 Faxed my letter and consent form to Blue Cross this morning and got a call from my investigative specialist within an hour. She confirmed the forms were received and Mr. Weiss can call or correspond directly with them on my behalf. She asked questions regarding attendance at the committee meeting, but I said I needed to call her back with that info. She gave me her direct number. I forwarded all info to Mr. Weiss and will see how he wants to handle.  lisa-e, I know the inconsistencies are complete BS, but they claim it all varies according to the policy. They try and make the employer look like the bad guy and that they didn't elect to have this coverage included in their policy. They are so full of it. This really has nothing to do with my husband's employer, rather it relates to the rights provided for women under the Cancer Act, etc.  PinkHeart, I do not believe my doctor's assistant was motivated to do much, even though my doctor had been very caring and compassionate. This was my experience with the assistant before my doctor transferred to a different department, so it was no surprise when she never called me and told me when she faxed things so I could follow up. SHE wouldn't always return my calls or email. Oh, and the kicker (sorry if I am repeating myself) was when Blue Cross called her and said they never received the five articles my doctor sent with her appeal letter. The assistant said she no longer had the articles, but that I did and they should contact me. Well, Kira and Binney had helped me pull those together and I had sent the articles to the assistant as electronic documents that were attached in an email. She had agreed to print them and fax them with my doctor's letter. I believe she printed and faxed them, but unless she had deleted my email (which I would consider part of my medical record), she still had those freakin' electronic documents, and all she had to do was attach in an email and send to Blue Cross. Instead, it looked like those articles came from me, and I was left explaining that the doctor had originally sent these with her letter of appeal. I probably would have been better off handling the appeal myself. Blue Cross' unwillingness to honestly answer questions posed to them on the phone makes me nuts. They deliberately lie or speak in gibberish. For example, Mr. Weiss had asked me to get copies of IBX's (Blue Cross in Phila area) policy bulletins regarding compression garments, looking for info on coverage as a result of lymphedema resulting from a mastectomy. So, I look at IBX's website and cannot seem to find any documents other than basic info about my coverage and how to appeal. My handbook has more info but not what I want. So I am googling and come up with results for medical policies on compression garments for practically every state in the union except PA's or IBX's. I call IBX, tell them what I want, and I am referred to my handbook regarding my coverage or that I can go to their website and look at all the other individual policies to see what their coverage provides for compression garments. I state that I want their general policy on compression garments, and she says she doesn't have that. Oh, and once again I am referred to my husband's employer as to compression garment coverage. Ugh. So I get really pissed off and sit and root around their freakin website for almost and hour, and finally!!! Bingo! Way down I find a page on policy, and when I click on it, a page comes up that urges patients to ask their doctors to review these documents because they have big fancy medical terms that they might not understand. F@$k you. Click. And there they are in their entirety. I print them before they can somehow magically disappear and then scan and send them. I had a giant three-ring binder on my BC testing, six biopsies that took three months before I actually got a final diagnosis and then had surgery. My pathology reports, recovery instructions, etc. went in there. I had a separate binder for my implant reconstruction and stuff from my plastic surgeon. I have a lymphedema file, and I also have a file for my deconstruction (Blue Cross was a nightmare about that), and I guess I need to start a new one for the appeal(s). Files, files, files . . . but they are absolutely necessary because at some point you just can't remember everything.

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2011 03:09PM Tina337 wrote: I turned the corner on Friday. Woke up without an upset tummy, which did a world of good for my outlook. Binney, I want to thank you for your comment about my decision not being a bad one, rather that I had a bad outcome. It really resonated with me and helped ease the regret. Thank you for putting that experience right in my head. Your thoughtful words often touch each of us so deeply, and you are such a kind soul. I'm so glad you are a member of this forum. Friday I found myself bopping up and down the stairs in our house, noticing the lightness without the weight of the implants and pain. I was dressed and had the thought that if I focus on what I am doing rather than how I look, that I can do this, no matter what my final appearance is. Many people have been dealt a crappy hand, and they go on and live happy and productive lives. There's no reason why I can't. I have a husband who loves me and a happy home. Except for some financial woes, which hopefully will be ironed out when I can return to work, my life is everything I have ever wanted. So, I'm looking at the positive and learning to move on while my body, heart and soul heal from this long journey. Last night, out with friends celebrating my husband's birthday, I found myself laughing harder than I have in quite a while. I think that's a very good sign! In some ways, life is good if you say it is . . SleeveNinja - About the compression tank, I have broad shoulders, and even though I am thin, I have found it hard to find garments that don't cut in my back or underarms. For me, Maidenform's "Control It" tank is best. With my implants, I wore a large, but I may fit in a medium now. I use the round Swell Spots under my arms that Binney mentioned. They don't always get around back if I have a flare or extra swelling though. I have pieces of orange foam my therapist cut that cover each side of my trunk and extend around back that I use for sleep at those times. I have an X-large tank for that get up. I remember my therapist showing me crescent shaped inserts that I think would have worked well, esp. around in the back, but they didn't extend down the side if my trunk enough. I have noticed that without the implants my compression tanks are much more comfortable and don't cut under my arms or back as much. Naturally, I am thrilled about that.

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2012 04:00AM Tina337 wrote: Not to be a negative Nellie here, but there is such a thing as neck LE. When my LE therapist was showing me a catalog for night garments, I saw all kinds of pads for face, head, neck LE. During Dr. Massey's presentation, she specifically talked about using the contralateral node, not neck node. I don't know if she is doing this now, and I hope anyone who attends her next conference asks her this question.  Here are some links with info on neck LE.  http://www.lymphnotes.com/article.php/id/378/ In this next link, scroll down to see articles related to LE after head and neck surgeries and the types of treatment:  www.lymphedemapeople.com/thesi...  Also:  http://www.cancer.net/patient/All+About+Cancer/Cancer.Net+Feature+Articles/Side+Effects/Head+and+Neck+Lymphedema%3A+Swelling+After+CanceReallr+Treatment I'm not trying to dismiss hope, but rather bring to light the known risks of taking nodes from the neck. I am just as eager for an answer that will end our suffering.

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2009 09:20PM Tina337 wrote: My sister-in-law lent me her Lazy-Boy and I lived and slept in that chair.  I had a bilat mast with expanders placed at the time of surgery.  First, I found the chair very helpful for sleeping and sitting immediately after surgery because the pectoral muscles had been cut and it was hard for me to raise myself up and out of bed.  You don't realize how much pectoral involvement is required for many tasks until you've got none!  The chair gave me the mobility to get up and use the bathroom in the middle of the night without help from my husband.  We put it in the living room and I could turn the light on and read or watch TV without bothering DH.  My sleep schedule was really off during that time. I had a painful expansion process and also slept in the chair after fills.  Sleeping on an inclined chair was more comfortable for me than laying in bed with pillows.  My pectoral muscles were cut again when I had the implant exchange, and I slept in the chair for a while after that surgery, too.   Everyone is different, but I really was attached to my recliner and found it helpful.   My friend who had a bilat mast with expanders slept on her living room sofa and found that more comfortable than the bed immediately after surgery.   Sounds like you have a plan as far as renting a chair to try it out.  I wish you good luck and a successful surgery on the 10th!! Hugs, Tina

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2010 11:11AM Tina337 wrote: I wore my compression tank 24/7 from May to December this past year. Had to add swell spots under my arm at times.  At night, I used a firmer foam insert that covered the side of my trunk and went half way around my back.  Had to use a slightly larger camisole to fit that.  Only times I was without the garment was while showering and changing camisoles at night.  I, too, cried a lot after a couple months of this.  I felt extremely claustrophobic.   I've been camisole-free since Dec. at the suggestion of my physiatrist/LE specialist, and we have been tracking my measurements.  I do wear the camisole and sleeve when exercising or exerting myself.  I can't believe the difference it has made in how I feel.  I am better emotionally, but there is also a physical sense of freedom and of being more "in my body" somehow.

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 04:44PM Tina337 wrote: Hello, my swell friends! Well, the implants are out, and it is an immense relief to not have that implant poking through my muscle or my chest muscles pulling and spasming on the outer side of my chest due to the capsular contracture. The PS said both capsules were quite thick. I received the full proactive treatment with Dr. Massey and staff. Both arms were wrapped by Dr. Massey, BP taken on calf, IV in neck. No questions asked. What I found most interesting is how Dr. Massey tailored my surgery so that it would have the least impact on my LE. In order to remove all the extra skin that had been created for the implant, she would have had to create large incisions that ran around the side of my chest. After seeing that the side of my chest is my main LE area, she decided against that kind of incision since it might disrupt the pathway I've been using for MLD. Instead, she cut a two inch incision on each side closer toward the sternum. She also placed the drains below the breast area vs the side since the scar from that might effect the MLD path. She had said I might need a second surgery to make everything tidy, but that she'd be able to do that with only a small incision and wouldn't effect my LE. I wasn't keen on a second surgery but knew she was right about protecting my MLD path. Post surgery, my arms were unwrapped. Dr. Massey reported she was pleased with the results and said I probably wouldn't need a second surgery. Going to see how the skin shrinks and everything heals. I know this seems crazy, but I actually think my chest LE is down even though I had surgery in the immediate area. My arm is fine, and both of my hands feel like my "old" hands. It's clear my body didn't want these implants in me and is happy they're gone. haven't felt emotional about the loss of my implants - guess I mourned when I made the decision to deconstruct and in the days leading up to the surgery. I'm just incredibly happy to feel good again. Can't imagine I'm going to feel even better once the incisions heal. Had MLD the day after my surgery and today, and I'm scheduled for MLD every day next week. One drain will probably be removed when I see Dr. Massey on Monday, but I'm hoping the second one cooperates and can go at the same time. Time to take my meds and get some rest. Looking forward to catching up on the discussions here. I've missed you guys! Tina
Posts.Title: Surgery finally happening Tina337 Tina337

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2011 08:43PM Tina337 wrote: Still here in Charleston, as my LE physiatrist recommended I stay long enough to get drains removed by Dr. Massey. I have had such a great experience here. I've been scheduled for daily MLD sessions with the therapist since being released from the hospital. She has been very good. I was so elated by the relief I felt from the removal of my implants, that it took me a while to bottom out. Dr. Massey had warned me I'd probably have some crying spells, but I was still surprised when they came on like a great flood. I was already tired of being a patient, had become cranky and weepy by the time I had my first appt with Dr. Massey after being released from the hospital. After she removed one drain, she explained exactly what she found during surgery and what she had been able to repair. It was clear a lot of damage had occurred during the expansion phase, and it's no wonder since it was painful as hell. Anyway, some of the muscle couldn't be repaired because it was so thin and wispy. As a result, for now I have a little ledge above my incision that may or may not retract and lie flat. We are hoping I don't need to return for a second surgery. Anyway, I think it finally sunk in exactly what I had subjected my body to. I have been having great feelings of regret for what I have done to myself, even though I know I made the best decision I could during a stressful time. I thought I was informed, but obviously not as much as I could have been. It's going to take some time to come to terms with the body I have been left with, and I know I need to be patient and give it six months to allow the skin and muscle time to retract (like a tummy after pregnancy). However, I am going to need to work on trying to forgive myself. I am so upset that I wasn't just grateful enough to beat cancer, but had to have boobs, too. I almost passed on the recon, and it was always my plan to never replace implants when their shelf life expired. I wish I had just known better. So much wasted time and pain. I had one drain removed the day before yesterday, and yesterday morning I woke up with some swelling - bad side of trunk. It was a rainy day, I've been slipping on hydration and it's been difficult to control salt. Anyway, the therapist wrapped my trunk and put yellow foam inserts on the sides below my arm pits. No fun with that remaining drain pinching underneath, as well as the bandaged drain site. Slept very poorly last night. Wore my tank and swell spots to therapy today to show therapist my original compression treatment garment. She liked it and said was okay if I preferred over wrapping. Bad news: four months again with the compression until everything settles down from surgery. Another blow to my fragile emotional state, and I slept poorly with the foam pressing on the edges of my back or firmly against my side. Ah, well. I know I came to the best place possible for LE care and surgery, so even though it's going to be a little while to get back to my pre-surgery state, I know I'm in better shape than if I had stayed local for the surgery.
Posts.Title: Surgery finally happening Tina337 Tina337

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2011 04:54PM Tina337 wrote: Thanks for your support and kind words. Blaming myself certainly doesn't help the situation, does it! I am trying to take it one day at a time and think positively. Some days I'm more successful than others. I think the physical stuff, still feeling somewhat bruised and raw - or having more sensation - combined with antibiotics that never agree with me, make me feel beaten down. Looking at all the extra skin and muscle that was left in order to avoid a longer incision in the LE area of my chest is just difficult to take. In contrast, yesterday I walked five miles with my husband, and today we did almost four. And, this morning at the LE therapist I was back down 2cm to my original post-surgery measurement. I do better when I keep myself busy, and I think when I get back home I'll feel better. Living out of a hotel room without a car and needing a cab to get places makes me feel I don't have much control. The salt factor has been difficult to control, and I am tired of restaurant food. My husband bought me a silver necklace yesterday - he was worried I wouldn't have anything positive to associate with Charleston. It is a stark contrast to our first trip here together 11 years ago. What a difference a decade can make! We were at such a different point in our lives, and we've both gone through so many changes. DH doesn't have to worry; I will always love Charleston. It is such a beautiful city. How can you not love the place Dr. Massey calls home!

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2010 03:20PM Tina337 wrote: Suzy, when you're good, you're very good, and when you're bad you're better!   Here's the positive thing LE has done for me, probably one of the best things to happen in my life. Cancer didn't even teach this lesson. LE imposed limits on what I could do, taking away many of my most favorite activities. I was devastated and mourned these losses. By the time I was 50, I had pretty much settled into enjoying an assortment of things that I knew brought me pleasure. I was very confused during the first year of adapting to LE, repeatedly discovering things I could no longer do. The big things were readily apparent, but the small things took longer to unfold and become obvious. I mourned as each was discovered. By the end of the year, I took an account of the list of activities I could no longer do, and it made me very sad. I remember sitting and thinking and crying. I knew my life had to go on - here I am after cancer and I am alive and healthy. I have a husband who loves me and a great group of friends and family. It suddenly occurred to me that it's a big world out there, and there are millions of things to do and enjoy. I could remain fixed on the things I can no longer do, or I could go out and discover new things that I CAN do. Just what a 50 yr old woman needs after becoming pretty comfortable with particular likes and dislikes - kind of boring, safe, and spoiled. I decided to let the remainder of my life be the time I use to explore new and different things. Either activities I didn't think I would like, or those that I hadn't even thought of or known about. It's been a real eye opener. It's sort of like being a kid again, willing to try and anticipate that I will have fun. And I have found that some of the newest things I've discovered are really wonderful. And I am grateful that I gave myself the chance to experience these things. Life is an adventure again. Also:   I think having LE has made me have to think more creatively. I've learned I have to let my needs be known and allow myself to appear more vulnerable in front of people. I've learned that people only know you as well as you let them. I think that is one of the things that makes our group here so wonderful. I've never met any of you in person, but I feel very close to all of you because you have so personally revealed yourselves. You are beautiful, and it is truly a privilege to know you. I have never met such compassionate and thoughtful women.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 06:58PM Tina337 wrote: I really appreciate the kind comments and support. Wish I didn't have as much company in dealing with insurance issues. Ugh! This shouldn't be so hard to get the gwrment I need. I have been trying to chill out and not let this bother me so much. My second level appeal hearing was today, and I attended via phone. Advocate reviewed info he sent to committee and did a great job. I did a quick summary of the makeshift getup I currently wear at night and why it's not very effective. The only questions they asked were: 1) the advocate's relationship to me, whether he received payment; 2) info on clinical trials about the vest; and 3) info on peer reviewed journal articles. Posts.Content: Jun 12, 2011 06:05PM Tina337 wrote: Mlpavone54, I finally had my implants removed on April 5. I feel so much better! It turned out that one implant had poked through the pectoral muscle, and the muscle on that side was damaged. Both sides had capsular contracture, and the capsules were quite thick. I wasn't sure how much relief I'd experience after the implants were removed, as a couple of PS's I consulted warned I may have post-mastectomy pain syndrome. Well, it was all implant pain, and now that they are gone, the scar tissue removed, and muscle repaired as much as possible on both sides, I am 100% pain free! Upon awaking from surgery, I could tell right away that much of the pain was gone. The post-surgery pain wasn't much worse than the implants! I am almost 10 weeks post surgery, and I feel like a new woman. There's no pain in my chest, and my back, neck and shoulder muscles are no longer tight. I have started to slowly exercise, and it feels good. I do have concavity in both sides of my chest where the expanders pressed on my ribcage. It's not quite the smooth and flat results I had hoped for, but I have adjusted to my appearance. I have't been wearing a prosthetic and I am happy with how I look in clothes.

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2011 07:12AM Tina337 wrote: Laura, I told my husband that I felt like Humpty Dumpty! All of me can't be put back together, but the existing parts are working better. I remember thinking before my surgery that if I felt 75% or even 50% better, then I would be happy with the results. Never in a million years did I think I would feel as good as I do. I believe there are people who have pain and problems that are completely implant related. Unfortunately, there's no way to know for sure unless you remove them. I had a gut feeling that all the chest muscle spasming and stabbing pain where I could feel the implant, and the tightness in my back, neck and shoulders were from the implants. The implants were noticeably misshapen, which was another indication. I consulted with two PTs and a physiatrist, who evaluated my body, and they thought I was right. I knew the implants were at least part of the problem, and because I wasn't willing to live with the pain anymore, any improvement would be a positive. My LE is easier to manage. I thought everything going on on the side of my trunk was LE related, but it turns out that half of the numb-y feeling I had was due to the implant. I can feel more and focus more accurately on the areas that need the most attention. There's no way to know exactly what's causing all of your pain, but please don't give up or think that you will never feel better. It is possible for your whole body, mind and soul to heal - I am living proof of that, and I hope you will soon have the chance to recover, too.

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2011 05:58PM Tina337 wrote: mlpavone, I did have drains after the surgery. Annoying and uncomfortable, but they are your friends! I had one for a week, and the other for almost two weeks. I probably would have had the second one removed a little earlier, but I got all gung ho and walked 5 miles two days in a row and that increased the output. The trick is to get some exercise every day, but not so much that it raises the output. Same thing as after the mastectomy - output has to be under 30cc for at least 3 days in a row before drain can be removed.  Laura, I think you're right about steering away from multiple surgeries when you have LE. That advice was given to me by a few professionals. More surgeries equal more scar tissue, which is definitely not good with LE. Did you see my thread on the LE forum that I started when I had my surgery? I must have mentioned Dr. Massey removed my implants - I feel like a broken record singing her praises. She was so careful about my LE. I will bump up my thread ("Surgery finally happening") in case you haven't seen. I also posted on the Charleston Bound 2 thread. While you may feel stuck because you have limited choices where you are located, maybe your insurance will grant an exception if you need to travel out of network to have surgery done by someone who can provide the best care for your LE .

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 06:53AM Tina337 wrote: ((((((Anne))))))  My heart goes out to you. From your post, I get a real sense of what this experience must be like for you. The clothing thing, ugh! Right there with you on that. I am a member of the photo forum, and I just couldn't spend any time there for quite a while. It was too depressing with pics of all the wonderful results. On the reconstruction threads, I no longer had anything to contribute and didn't want to sound like a "downer". I, too, wondered how I got here and sometimes regretted my decision. The drs. made it sound so easy . . . Sure, I read the risks, but I've always been fit and healthy and assumed I would be fine. I think having immediate recon is somewhat like having a safety net as far as emotionally dealing with the loss of your breasts. The loss is there, but recon gives us something to focus on, to look forward to. And it's marketed as a prize - like a boob job or once again having the boobs from your youth. Well, when the safety net is drawn away, the emotional pain of losing our breasts surfaces again. We also worry about what we will look like if we deconstruct - worse than if we never had recon? Well, I've been living for two years with pain, disfigured implants and lymphedema. Perhaps a long, drawn out process is worse than just a quick "off with their heads". I mourned when I finally decided to deconstruct - worries about my appearance, as well as concern over whether surgery would make my lymphedema worse. Well, they have to come out sometime, so they might as well be now. At this point, the process has become debilitating for me, and I need to get back with living and thinking about other things. So, I am finally ready to go - let the chips fall where they may.  Anne, I wish I could help take away that ashamed feeling. The problems of the recon are not your fault. Someone on another thread likened recon to a crap shoot. There is a percentage of people who will develop problems after recon - it's just a fact. WE are not failures. Our bodies didn't take to the process, and we don't need to blame ourselves. I know my PS wouldn't say it was HIS failure, so why should I? And you don't need to shoulder any blame for what happened to you, either. I know you will come to decide what's right for you with this process, Anne. I wish you peace and clarity, and freedom from the physical part of this. The women on this forum are quite helpful with info about prosthetics, dressing, and have a great attitude about living breast free. If having breasts is important to you, then please know there are many other procedures out there besides implants. I don't have experience or detailed knowledge of them, but the women on the recon forum will gladly help provide info on these other techniques.  Tina

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2010 06:23AM Tina337 wrote: Thank you, Kira, for your response. Just peeled myself off the sofa - lying down to elevate foot and minimize sneezing/runny nose. I will make sure to watch for cellulitis. I do have a few capsules of clindamycin on hand for dental and GI procedures since I have implants, mitral valve prolapse and I'm allergic to Keflex. I happen to have my annual appt. with my gynecologist tomorrow morning, so if there is an antibiotic that is best for fending off cellulitis, I would have the opportunity to ask her for a script while I'm there. It really makes sense to have that on hand in case of an emergency. What you're saying about the inflammatory response being in high gear makes sense. I usually limit the amount of ibuprofen I take after developing an NSAID induced ulcer a few years ago. Naproxen is out because that definitely tears up my stomach, but a little bit of ibuprofen carefully spaced out seems to be okay. I haven't had the need to take more than my itty bitty doses occasionally so I never noticed whether it increased swelling for me. I hadn't even heard about its possible effect on LE until recently.  Sounds like the benedryl, sudafed or mucinex are okay as long as I stay hydrated. I've been taking the benedryl at night since it helps me sleep and taking the sudafed during the day since it keeps me awake. Both drugs taken at the same time make me feel like a wacko, which is sort of where I am at this point after taking both several days in a row. I will have to check my drug cabinet to see what I have on hand - I may have a bottle of some allergy med I decided was the least offensive as far as side effects. I do so poorly with drugs, so I usually save old prescription bottles so I can remember what is actually okay for me to take. Fortunately, the benedryl isn't an issue since I'm not taking tamoxifen. I'm also going to pick up a neti pot at the drug store tomorrow after my appt.  Kira, thank you again for your help. It is greatly appreciated.  Tina

When I was away on vacation once, I tried to purchase Simply Saline spray but could only find the store brand. Didn't give it a second thought and bought it. Well, after using it, I felt out of sorts so I compared the label against my empty can of Simply Saline. I noticed the benzo-stuff you mentioned and figured that must be the cause. Sometimes I really hate having a body that is so sensitive to drugs, but I guess that can be a good thing.  I think having BC makes us all a bit crazy when it comes to tests and being in the role of the patient. I don't trust my body, and I don't always trust my drs. It all makes for a little insanity now and then - just to keep life interesting! Thanks for the well wishes! Tina

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2011 11:20AM - edited Nov 6, 2011 11:21AM by Tina337 I would be interested to know if in general I should refrain from doing that, as I sometimes feel the need to stretch my chest and neck because of the scarring I developed from the reconstruction. When I had my implants, it pulled my shoulders and everything forward and down due to their weight, capsular contracture and scar tissue. When I had the implants removed and the muscles put back in their normal position and tacked to the chest wall, my chest felt so much more "open" and I could breathe more easily. I have been to my myofascial release therapist and he has worked on my chest twice since the surgery. First time was about 10 wks after, and then again this past week. I had definitely tightened up somewhat, but nothing like when I had the implants. Anyway, toward the end of the session, he worked on the area just above the breast area, and I could feel the tightness all the way into my neck. Obviously, this is all connected. So, I want to go back again and have him work some more on this area. Then I probably wouldn't feel the need to lean my head back to stretch my neck and upper chest. I am now wondering if there are stretches that safely address the neck and upper chest. For me, this is just another example of how implant recon really messes with the structure of your body and is not the simple surgery that plastic surgeons suggest it is.

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2010 10:23AM Tina337 wrote: Laura, I hope you don't mind my asking, but I am curious to know when you developed LE. I just don't recall your ever mentioning it on the recon threads or picture forum. Did it occur after a certain part of the recon? Boy, this sure wasn't what we had in mind after going through that grueling process, was it? I will have to forego the nipple recon and 3D tattoos, as it's too much of a risk with my truncal LE. I have CC in my right implant, but I'm trying to avoid surgery to replace. Have been doing myofascial therapy, which has helped a lot with the pain and appearance of the implant. So for now, that's the track I'm on. I still struggle a little emotionally with my results since I no longer can wear a bra. My LE physiatrist and LE therapist actually agreed that I do better without anything at this point, so I really shouldn't complain. The bun shape implants and the CC in the right side have made dressing tricky. After having meltdown after meltdown when I tried to get dressed, I finally went through my closets and drawers and threw out anything that made me cry. I don't look or feel like I thought I would at the end of all this, but, hey, I'm here. I think the first summer with LE is the worst. I was in the middle of the intensive treatment phase last July and August, and flaring big time. To top it off, I was really uncomfortable and hot with the compression garments and phasing into menopause. Relatively speaking, this summer seems much better. I'm not flaring as much, but it's probably because I have the tools for self care and have had a good amount of time to determine things that help and things to avoid. I think emotionally, last summer was awful because everything was such a big unknown, and I had had to fight my drs. to get the right treatment. I hadn't even fully gotten used to having new boobs, and then wham! it was LE and CC time. Thanks to all the wonderful women on this forum, I was pointed in the right direction and gained insight into what the future might be and became hopeful that I, too, could learn to manage chronic LE. I still hate it - even fear it - but I've come just a little closer to accepting what I have been through and where I am.
